abstracts.cdata!:
The Krakow Energy Efficiency Project for
            Poland had a moderately satisfactory outcome and a moderate
            risk to development outcome. Both the Bank and the borrower
            performances were satisfactory. The main lessons learned
            from the project are: 1) When appraising a borrower for an
            entrepreneurial business, especially in a new market such as
            the one for ESCO services, the Bank should focus on the
            capacity of the borrower to be flexible and entrepreneurial.
            The Bank should consider if the right type of
            entrepreneurial people will be available to spearhead this
            new business model and if not, how such skills/attitudes can
            be brought in to the project. 2) When lending to a borrower
            that will enter an unfamiliar market, initial loan planning
            should focus on listing risks and mitigation strategies, and
            ensuring adequate liquidity to cover acceptable
            contingencies. 3) The opening of ESCO markets requires
            changes in the thinking of many stakeholders. The Bank
            should plan to provide direct technical assistance to a
            variety of entities beyond the borrower.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Krakow Energy Efficiency Project
            aims at improving the efficiency of the city's district
            heating (DH) systems, decrease heat energy consumption by
            improving energy efficiency at the end-user level, and,
            develop knowledge-based mechanisms to finance energy
            efficiency projects. The project components will: 1) support
            strategic, and development investments, through the
            connection of new DH, and domestic hot water (DHW) to
            customers. By connecting pipeline branches to a booster pump
            station, the transmission capacity will be increased,
            allowing the purchase, and dispatch heat from the cheaper
            source, thus reducing overall supply costs to customers, as
            well as improving heat supply reliability to the southeast
            region; 2) finance ecological investments, by sequentially
            discontinuing current coal-fired heat-only-boilers (HOBs),
            to instead connect customers to municipal heating systems. A
            certain amount of HOBs will be converted to gas, or
            oil-firing, co-financed by a grant from the Global
            Environment Facility (GEF), and, plans to eliminate coal
            stoves will be explored to protect the environment; 3)
            modernize heat exchanger stations, through the installation
            of plate heating exchangers in substations, and, by
            replacing heating networks with pre-insulated pipe
            technology; and, 4) finance heat efficiency investments, to
            include institutional strengthening, by providing
            computerization systems, and training to improve labor
            productivity; replacing the automation of the Krakow system,
            and a number of heat meters, as well as maintenance tools,
            and equipment. Funding for the Energy Service Company
            capitalization will be provided, to balance its business development.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Krakow Energy Efficiency Project :
            environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the environmental management
            plan for the Krakow Energy Efficiency Project which
            modernizes the district heating system for the city of
            Krakow. during the construction phase, negative
            environmental impacts such as noise, dust, and the
            construction phase, negative environmental impacts such as
            noise, dust, and This is the environmental management plan
            for the Krakow Energy Efficiency Project which modernizes
            the district heating system for the city of Krakow. During
            the construction phase, negative environmental impacts such
            as noise, dust, and traffic disruption will be offset by
            restricting construction operations to noraml daytime hours,
            weting surfaces when dry, hot, or windy, and placing warning
            signs and officials to redirect traffic. Disposal of
            scrap--both nonhazardous and asbestos--will be done by
            licensed operators at government-approved sites. During the
            operations phase, boiler emmissions will comply with Polish
            emission standards and World Bank guidelines. That is, low
            sulfur fuel oil and low nitrous oxide burners will be used.
            A chemical analysis (wet bubbler or automatic) will be done
            either once a year or continuously.
